author: _shemnon
content: What's the standard for censorship resistance and permissionlessness? The operational rollups still have admin keys ready in case bugs show up. And they also tend to run sequencers that provide high performance, but at least in the case of Arbitrum if you get a message to the L1 inbox you only need one honest staker to advance it.

author: _shemnon
content: The admin key is a full stop, but do privileged sequencers that must accept L1 posted messages break censorship resistance and prermissionlessness?

author: mightypenguin
content:
A floating gas limit was one of the amazing innovations of Ethereum early on and perhaps something like it could be extended for opcodes.
Has anyone looked at this?
We wouldn't have to allow all opcodes to float, but perhaps there could be an allowed list of ones that can.
Each client could either hard code the values, or have a benchmark suite to set those values for that client.
If worried about large farms pricing out smaller ones, the movement of prices could be limited so that the slowest/most-expensive execution clients would not be priced out too quickly.
